Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Opportunistic and Compressive Sensing in Wireless Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project investigates Opportunistic Sensing (OS) and Compressive Sensing (CS) in Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs). OS refers to a paradigm in which a WSN can automatically discover and select sensor modalities and sensors based on an operational scenario, resulting in an adaptive network that automatically finds scenario-dependent, objective-driven opportunities with optimized performance. CS is a novel sensing/sampling paradigm that goes against the common wisdom in data acquisition. Both OS and CS help improve efficient operations and performance of WSNs significantly. In particular, OS aims at reduction from space by selecting a subset of sensors and modalities for efficient data fusion, whereas CS targets reduction in sampling by selecting a subset of samples non-uniformly. Therefore, theoretical foundations and algorithms for opportunistic and compressive sensing are essential for advancing the state of the art in WSNs that not only ensure effective utilization of sensing assets but also provide robust optimal performance. This project addresses fundamental research issues from information theoretic viewpoint to evaluate joint OS and CS distortions, develop OS and collaborative CS schemes for better performance of WSNs, and cross-layer design to adapt to the non-uniform sampling in CS-based WSNs.
This project will make a significant contribution to the theory and applications of opportunistic and compressive sensing to WSNs and will have a broad and deep social impact in homeland security and defense. Under-represented and female students from different societies will be recruited, and seminars and in-house short courses will be offered to local industry via IEEE.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have achieved the following major research outcomes during the project period: i) we developed effective algorithms with very high accuracy to employ compressing sensing for localizing and counting sparse targets, and opportunistic sensing for counting dense targets; ii) we validated through experiments that the signal samples of radar sensors in the time domain can be largely compressed so that they could be recovered by a small number of measurements; iii) we demonstrated that in radar sensor networks a set of stepped-frequency (SF) waveforms can be used as pulse compression codes for transmit sensors, and as the sparse matrix to compress the signal in the receiving sensor, which can significantly decrease the amount of information that should be collected for target detection in RSNs; iv) we proposed a maximum likelihood algorithm to estimate the target radar cross section parameter and use the Cramer-Rao lower bound to validate our theoretical result; v) real world experiments indicate that radar signals can be perfectly reconstructed if the number of measurements is equal to or larger than the number of transmit sensors; and vi) we observed via experiments that the sense-through-foliage communication channels for three different radars (200MHz, 400MHz, and UWB radars) are sparse, and developed a sparse signal compression and recovery mechanism that can achieve a compression ratio of 32:1 with an almost perfect recovery.
